extraction_metadata.notes: Trial has complete documentation with detailed witness testimony and torture sessions. First witness (Louis Sauceratte, butcher) and start of second witness depositions are noted as missing in the document. The hayloft incident is central to multiple witnesses (2, 6, 7, 8) who all corroborate the death of wife of François Chartier. Mengeotte had clear pattern of confession under torture, retraction when torture stopped, and re-confession when tortured again. She ultimately withdrew accusations against named accomplices admitting they were motivated by hatred and desire for revenge. Her mother was previously executed as a witch, providing important family history context. Economic status assessed as 'poor' based on: dispute over spinning payment, begging for eggs, 11 children with only 3 surviving, domestic violence, and devil giving her worthless oak leaves as 'money'. Healing practice evidenced by bringing bread/salt/lard to cure paralysis and recommending herbal remedy (bruel). The trial shows extensive Change de Nancy involvement at every stage. Note: 'mal St Marcel' appears to be a disease name (possibly St. Marcellus disease/epilepsy). The phrase 'recognoissance' in witness 2's testimony is unclear in context - may refer to a legal obligation or acknowledgment.
